The present report includes proposals, experience and best practices that Greece would do well to apply.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) This report highlights objectives and principles for the processing and collection of economic statistics, specifically that their production should be independent and separate from the political process, making the Member States responsible for the accuracy and authenticity of statistical data. As this is certainly a principle that will enable results to be more certain and rigorous, I voted for this report.

 
  
 		 

  Robert Rochefort (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) Reliable and accurate statistics are essential to allow effective economic and budgetary policy making by the Member States and the European Union. The debt crisis in the euro area has also highlighted the dangers of statistical inaccuracy and statistical fraud, which are often caused by weaknesses in the quality of upstream public accounting data. I therefore believe that it is crucial for public decision makers to be supplied with relevant, timely and accurate data that are collected and compiled by national agencies in accordance with the principles of impartiality, objectivity and professional independence.

The report on quality management for European statistics calls on the Commission to provide assistance and expertise to the Member States with a view to helping them to ensure compliance and provide high-quality data across all levels of government. It also encourages Eurostat to disclose publicly whether it has doubts concerning the accuracy of all types of statistics. The report emphasises, too, that the independence of the statistical services must be safeguarded at both national and European level from the threat of possible political interventions. I supported the report.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour. This is a non-controversial report that highlights a certain number of highly consensual recommendations made by the European Parliament in order to enhance the quality management of economic statistics, including the following main elements:

- gradual transition is recommended from a corrective approach to a preventive approach to the quality management of European statistics in general and public finance statistics in particular;

- the Commission is urged to forward proposals for legislation aimed at introducing elements of the revised European Statistics Code of Practice into EU law, with a view to distinguishing clearly between the responsibilities and competences of national statistical agencies and those of Member State governments;

- Eurostat is encouraged to disclose publicly whether it has doubts concerning the accuracy across all types of statistics;

- Eurostat is urged to look at ways to make its publications, particularly those online, more user-friendly to the average citizen and non-professionals, especially with regard to the use of graphs; Eurostat’s website should, in particular, allow easier access to complete long-term data series and include intuitive comparative graphs (green input).

 
  
 		 

  Licia Ronzulli (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of this document because I think reliable and accurate statistics are essential to allow effective economic and budgetary policy making by Member States and at Union level. I believe that we need a systemic approach to quality, which may require a reform of the methods of producing European statistics and a gradual transition from a corrective approach to a preventive approach to the quality management of European statistics.

Furthermore, Eurostat must look at ways to make its publications, particularly those online, more user-friendly to the average citizen and non-professionals. Precise, accurate data constitute a basis for obtaining detailed information on individual areas such as demographics, the economy and the environment, and they therefore play a key role in the regional development decision-making process, in particular, in the context of Europe 2020 strategy implementation.

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Paolo Francesco Silvestris (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Eurostat has existed for nearly 60 years – since 1953 to be exact. It is an especially important office for the European Union, since reliable and accurate statistics are essential to allow effective economic and budgetary policy making by Member States and at Union level. This vote underscores the need to adopt a systemic approach to quality, which may require a reform of the method of producing European statistics. This has to be achieved without increasing costs. Indeed, we need to modernise the European statistics production methods in order to maintain cost-effectiveness. Furthermore, our approval goes towards safeguarding the credibility of statistical data and the absolute independence of the statistics body.

 
  
 		 

  Csaba Sógor (PPE), in writing. – (HU) The current European sovereign debt crisis, the implementation of our objectives for 2020, and the necessity of ensuring long-term economic growth and development at both micro- and macro-regional level all call for a coordinated, carefully planned EU economic policy backed by solid data. It is clear that actions intended to lay the foundations of the EU’s long-term economic development can only be based on accurate, objective figures that cannot be influenced by political entities. To this end, it is important for both the Member States and Eurostat to put accurate and reliable data at the disposal of political decision makers and the populace. This is a precondition of monitoring economic and demographic trends and of the ability to adjust any actions that prove to be deficient in due course. It is crucial for the Court of Auditors to review statistics submitted by Eurostat and the Member States, undertake regular financial audits, and use their expertise in the field to offer professional assistance on demand. In light of the above, I can only support this motion.

 
  
 		 

  Kay Swinburne (ECR), in writing. – The only way to have good economic policy in a country is if you can rely upon the quality of the statistics you are basing decisions upon. While there has been a lot of discussion over Greece’s use of inaccurate statistics in reporting to the European Commission, there is a more pressing concern in many countries that statistical agencies are not properly independent from government and are overly influenced by politicians to produce favourable forecasts and statistics to back up questionable economic decisions.

I am really supportive of Mr Scicluna’s report in this area as it reinforces the economic governance legislation that we concluded last year and looks to achieve meaningful, practical improvements to how statistics are collected and how they are used.

I continually ask both the Commission in its impact assessments, and private sector organisations when they are criticising EU legislation, to back up their arguments with facts and data, and I hold Member States to the same goal – good policy can only be made if it is based upon solid evidence that stands up to scrutiny.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Teixeira (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The European Commission has published a communication, the purpose of which is ‘to set out a strategy that would give the European Union a quality management framework for statistics related to enhanced economic policy coordination’. As such, I voted for this report, because I believe that a systemic approach to quality European statistics should be adopted, that a more proactive approach to managing and evaluating data on the public finances at an early stage should be encouraged, and that greater rigour in statistics should be emphasised at all levels of government. I also believe that Eurostat should modernise its methods for producing European statistics, so as to maintain the cost/efficiency relationship, and to ensure that accounting and publishing systems are standardised across the various Member States, using internal and external auditing methods for oversight. Finally, I should like to stress the need to develop a coherent system for researching socio-economic processes in cross-border areas, including the outermost regions, with a view to obtaining a reliable, complete and precise economic framework for regional development.

 
  
 		 

  Silvia-Adriana Ţicău (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for the report on quality management for European statistics because independent, high-quality statistics are needed to guarantee economic growth and employment. Users of statistics must have access to relevant, accurate and timely data which are collected and compiled by national agencies in accordance with the principles of impartiality, objectivity and professional independence. Accurate data provide a basis for obtaining detailed information and analysing areas such as demographics, the economy and the environment. This is why they play a key role in the decision-making process affecting regional development. Eurostat publications, particularly those online, need to be more user-friendly for the average citizen and non-professionals. Eurostat’s website should allow easier access to complete data and include intuitive, comparative graphs in order to provide the public with greater added value and clarity. Member States should ensure that statistics are accurate across every level of government. We encourage Eurostat to disclose publicly whether it has doubts about the accuracy of any type of statistics. We call on the Commission and Member States to take the measures required to enhance Eurostat’s independence, including amendments to its institutional status.

 
  
 		 

  Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE), in writing. – (LT) The report rightly observes that reliable statistics are essential for effective policy making at Member State and Union level. I believe that statistics should be publicly accessible and easily understandable by both policy makers and citizens. They should also be fair and unbiased. The greatest problem in Lithuania today is the difference between what official statistics say about economic activity and how people perceive their living conditions. Often, this difference stems not from the poor quality of official statistics, but from their inappropriate use. This can lead to biased analysis and inappropriate policy objectives, and may damage both confidence in political action and the functioning of Lithuanian democracy. For example, although the Lithuanian Government and its statistics point to economic recovery and improvement, the reality is rather different. The latest report by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development has revealed that in recent years, satisfaction with life in Lithuania has fallen by 10%. The report states that young Lithuanians’ confidence in a better future has also fallen by 20%. We must restore confidence and we can only achieve this if political actions – supported by unbiased statistics – have a tangible impact on people’s lives.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – The report on quality management for European statistics stresses the urgent necessity to provide better quality statistics within the EU. It is extremely necessary to enforce a European Statistics Code of Practice in order to have impartial, transparent and objective statistics not only at an EU level, but also at a national level, in cooperation with national bodies. As this report also establishes more user-friendly publications to help citizens understand statistics, I voted in favour of this report.

 
  
 		 

  Marina Yannakoudakis (ECR), in writing. – I was pleased to support this report as what use are statistics if they cannot be trusted? Reliable and accurate statistics are important for policy making, particularly economic and budgetary related. The report highlights the need for impartiality and objectivity in addition to ensuring that statistics are compiled by national agencies separate from political control. We must not let political parties meddle with statistics and skew them to their advantage. I hope that by streamlining the entire production chain, we shall have increasingly accurate facts and figures which have been properly verified and that we can have confidence in.

 
  
 		 

  Janusz Władysław Zemke (S&D), in writing. – (PL) I strongly support the report on quality management for European statistics. This is one of the prerequisites for the European Union to be able to increase its level of supervision over the budgets of individual Member States. We have had negative experiences with blatant cases of false statistics concerning levels of public debt, as in the case of Greece. Eurostat, which has been in existence since 1953, has therefore rightly gained new powers. These changes should improve the situation in two respects. Firstly, users of statistics will receive more accurate and timely data. Secondly, statistical data will become more readily available to citizens and more easily understood by them. The report therefore deserves our support.

 
  
 		 

  Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) This report highlights objectives and principles that we advocate regarding the processing and collection of economic statistics; specifically, that their production should be independent and separate from the political process, making the Member States responsible for the accuracy and authenticity of statistical data. The report also mentions the need to safeguard the independence of statistical services from the threat of potential political interference, at both national and European level.

However, a number of the report’s other premises totally contradict these principles, particularly when it mentions that statistics should produce the data used for monitoring the results of economic governance and the ‘six-pack’, which are nothing more than policies associated with the leaders of the European institutions and the governments that back them.

We would argue that statistical indicators should be at the service of a full knowledge of social and economic realities and that they should not be selected with a view to pursuing political objectives, particularly when these run completely counter to defending the development of social progress.

 
Legal notice - Privacy policy
